messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Eric Armstrong <eric.armstrong@s...> wrote:
> Thanks, Dave. Great writeup.

Thanks.

> But at this point I've lost track of how that discussion applies to
> the problem of testing private methods.

True.

> What was your solution to that problem?

I don't.

Also, I don't intentionally make private methods. They are generally
a result of refactoring. Another place I'll have privates is if I am
sing factory methods for instantiation. Then I'll have private
constructors.

Private methods aren't part of the external behavior of the system, so
it needn't be directly tested. TDD drives the design and
implementation of the external behavior. So you code the external
behavior to pass the test. When you cleanup by refactoring and start
extracting bits, those extracted methods are structural, not
behavioral, so I make them private.

As mentioned before, there are times when a subset of a class can be
extracted, then maybe some of the private methods that go with it
change to publis.. as makes sense. But if that's going to happen.. it
has to happen in response to a failing test.

Dave
